XX - 93 97
It has been already mentioned
that the tribes which Sebituane
subjected in this great country
pass by the general name
of Makalaka - The Makololo
were composed of ^ a great
numbers of other tribes as
well as of these central negroes
The nucleus of the whole were
BasutauBasuto who came from
a comparatively cold and
hilly region in the South with
trtranspose Sebituane - When he conquered
various tribes of the Bechuanas
as Bakwains - Bangweaketze
Bamangweato - Batauana &c
he incorporated the young
of these tribes into his own
Great mortality ^ by fever having
taken place in the original
stock he wisely adopted the
same plan of absorption
on a large scale with the
Makalaka - so we found
him with even the sons of
the chiefs of the Barotse
closely attached to his person
and they say to this day if
anything else but natural
death had assailled their
father every one of them
would have laid down his
life in his defence - One
reason for their strong affection
94 98
was their emancipation by
the decree "all are children of
the chief"

They ^ The Makalaka cultivate the Caffre
sorghum or dourha dur
DourhaDourra - (doora) as the
principal grain - with
maize, two kinds of beans
Earth nuts (arachis hypogoeaarachis hypogaea)
pumpkins water melons
and cucumbers - They
depend for success entirely
upon rain - Those who
live in the Barotse valley
cultivate in addition the
sugar cane, sweet potato
and manioc (Jatropha manihot)
The climate there however
is warmer than at
Linyanti and theythe Makalaka
increase the fertility of
their gardens by rude
attempts at artificial
irrigation

The instrument of
culture over all this region
is a hoe (see page )
the iron of which is obtained
95 99
from the ore by the Batoka
and Banyeti by smelting
The amount of iron which
they produce annually
may be understood when
it is known that most
of the whohoes in use at
Linyanti are the tribute
imposed on the smiths

Sekeletu recievesreceives tribute
from a great number
of tribes in corn or dourhadourra
ground nuts - hoes - spears
honey - canoes, paddles ^ wooden vessels
tobacco, Mutoku-
-ane (cannabis
sativa)
various wild fruits
dried - prepared skins, and
ivory - When these articles
appear in the Kotla Sekeletu
has the honour of dividing
them among the loungers
who usually congregate
there - A small portion
only is reserved for
himself - The ivory belongs
nominally as into the the
same to him too but this
is simply a way of making
a fair distribution of the
profits - The chief sells it
only with the approbation
of his counsellors and
proceeds are distributed
in open day among the
people as before - He has
96 4100
the choice of all - but if he is
not more liberal to others
than ^ to himself he loses in
popularity - I have known
instances in this and other
tribes in which individuals
aggrieved because they
had been overlooked fled
to other chiefs - One such
having fled to Lechulatebe
was encouraged to go
to a village of the Bapalleng
on the river Chō or Tsō
and abstracted the tribute
of ivory thence - This theft
enraged the whole of the
X
Qu:Query this
QuQuery on the 8th day Makololo because they
all felt it to be a personal
loss - Some of LechulatebesLechulatebe's
people having come onX
the 8th a demonstration
was made in which about
500 Makololo armed
went through a mimic
fight - The principal
warriors pointed their
spears towards the Lake
where Lechulatebe lives
and every thrust in that
direction was answered
by by all with the shout "hōō" while
every stab on the ground
drew out the a simultaneous
huz "huzz" - On such occasions
all capable
of bearing arms
even the old
must turn out
at the call - In
the time of Sebituane
anyone remaining
in his house was
searched for and
killed without mercy -

97 101
This offence of Lechulatebe
was aggravated by repetition
and a song sung in his
town onin dances which
manifested joy at the death
of Sebituane - He had
enjoined his people to live
in peace with those at the
Lake and Sekeletu felt
disposed to follow his advice
but Lechulatebe had now
got possession of fire arms
and considered himself more
than a match for the Makololo
His father had been dispossessed
of many cattle by Sebituane
and as forgiveness is
not considered among the
virtues by the heathen he
thought he had a right
to recover what he could
As I had a good deal of
influence with the Makololo
I persuaded them that before
they could have peace
they must resolve to give
the same blessing to others
and they never could do
that without forgiving
and forgetting ancient feuds
It is hard to make them
feel that shedding of human
blood is a ^ great crime - They must
feel it to be wrong but having
98 102
having been accustomed to
bloodshed from infancy
they are remarkably callous
to the enormity of ^ the crime taking
of destroying ^ human life

I sent a message at
the same time to Lechulatebe
advising him to give up
the course he had adopted
and especially the song
because though Sebituane
was dead the arms with
which he had fought were
still alive and strong -

Sekeletu in order to
follow up his fathersfather's instructions
and promote peace sent
ten cows to be exchanged
for sheep - These animals
thrive well in a bushy
country like that around
the Lake but will scarcely
live in the flat prairies
between the net worknetwork of
waters north of the Chobe
The men who took the
cows and sent back
an equal number of sheep,
Now Accordingaccording to the ^ relative value
of sheep & cows in these
parts he ought to have sent sixty or seventy

99 103
One of the men who had hoes
was trying to purchase in
a village without formal
leave from Lechulatebe,
This chief punished ^ him by
making him sit some
hours on the broiling
hot sand (at least 130˚) This
farther offence put a stop
to amicable relations altogether
It was a case in which
a very weak
tribe commanded
by a weak &
foolish chief one of the parties had got
possession of fire arms
and felt conscious of
ability to cope with a
powerful and warlike race
This isSuch cases are ^ the only ones
in which the possession
of fire arms does evil -
133 [The universal effect of
of the diffusion of the more
skillful potent instruments
of warfare ^ in Africa is the same as
among ourselves - They
Firearms render wars
less frequent and less
bloody - It is indeed exceeding-
-ly rare to hear of atwo tribes
having guns going to
war with each other - And
as nearly all the feuds have
been,- in the South at least,-
about cattle - The risk which
must be incurred from long
shots generally proves a
preventative to the attempts forays

100 8104
The Makololo were pre-
-vailed upon to keep the peace
during my residence
with them but it was
easy to percieveperceive that public
opinion was against
sparing a tribe of Bechuanas
for whom the Makololo
entertained the most sovreignsovereign
contempt - The young men
would remark "Lechulatebe
is herding our cows for us"
"Let us only go we shall "lift"
QuQuery prize the price" &c -of them in sheep" &c

As the Makololo are the
most northerly of the Bechuanas
we may glance back at this
family of Africans before
entering on the branch
of the negro family which
the Makololo distinguish by
the term Makalaka -
The name Bechuana seems
derived from the word
chuana = alike or equal with
the personal pronoun Ba = they
prefixed - and therefore means
fellows or equals - Some
have supposed the name
101 105
to have arisen from a mistake
of some traveller who on
asking individuals of this
nation concerning the tribes
living beyond them recievedreceived
the answer Ba-chuana = they
(are) alike - meaning they are
the same as we are, and that
this nameless traveller who
never wrote a word about them
managed to ^ engraft his mistake
as a generic term for a nation
extending from the Orange
river to 18˚ South Latitude - * foot note
* The Makololo
have conquered
the country as
far as 124˚ South
but it is still
peopled chiefly
by the black
tribes named
Makalaka
As the name was found in use
among those who had no inter-
-course with Europeans, and
before we can recievereceive the above
explanation we must believe
that the unknown traveller
knew the language sufficiently
well to ask a question but
not ^ to understand the answer
we may add that the way in
which they still continue to
use the word seems to require
no fanciful interpretation
When addressed with any degree of
scorn - They reply "We are
Bechuana or equals - we are
not inferior to any of own nation
Inin exactly the same sense
as an Irishman or Scotchman
in the same circumstances
who would reply "We are Britons" or we are Englishmen
102 106
Most other tribes are known
by the terms applied to them
by strangers as the Caffres, Hottentots
& Bushmen - The Bechuanas
alone use the term themselves
as a generic term for the whole
nation - They have managed
also to give a comprehensive
name to the whites, viz -videlicet Makōa
though they cannot explain
the derivation of it noany more
than of their own - It seems
to mean "handsome" from the
manner in which they use it
to indicate "beauty", though
there is another word very
like it meaning "infirm" or
"weak" The people they term
Bechuanas their language
SechuanaSetswana and the whites
Makōa, their language sekōa, The language of the
Bechuanas, they
term SechuanaSetswana;
that of the Whites
(Makōa) they
term Sekōa.

The Makololo or
BasutauBasuto have carried their
powers of generalization
still farther and arranged
the other parts of the same
great family of South
Africans into three
divisions - ^ 1st The MatibeleMatebele or
Makonko-bi are, the
Caffre family living on the
Eastern side of the country -
2nd The Bakoni or tribes
living BasutuBasuto - ^ 3rd the Bechuanas
living in central parts
103 107
parts, and the Bakalahari
namwhich includes all those
tribes living in or adjacent to on the
borders of The Great Kalahari
desert -

1st. The Caffres are divided by
themselves into various sub
divisions as Amakosa
Amapanda &c - &c - and other
well known termstitles - They
consider the name Caffre as
an insulting epithet - As my
remarks are intendintended to
apply more particularly
to the Bechuanas I proceed
to enumerate the tribes
into which they are divided -
The Zulaus of Natal belong
to the same family and
they are as famed for their
honesty as their bretheren
who live adjacent to our
Colonial Frontier are
renowned for cattle lifting
Of them the Recorder of
Natal declared that history
does not present another
instance in which so
much security for life
and property has been
enjoyed, as has been experi-
-enced byduring the whole period
of English occupation by
10,000 colonists in the midst
of 100,000 Ca Zulus .

104 12108
The MatibeleMatebele of MosilikatzeMosilikatse
living a short distance South
of the Zambesi, and other
tribes living a little South
of SennaSena and Tete are
members of this same family
They are not knownknown beyond
the ZambesiZambezi river - This
was the limit of the Bechuanas
QuQuery this word?
progress Northing too, untilluntil Sebituane
pushed his conquests farther

2d The Bakoni and
BasutusBasuto ^ division contains in the
South all those tribes which
acknowledge Moshesh
as their paramount chief
^ The Batau
The Baputi
Makolokue &c - and some mountaineers
on the range Maluti, who
are believed by those who
have carefully sifted the
evidence, to have been
at one time ^ guilty of cannaibalism -
This has been doubted but
their songs admit the fact
to this day and they ascribe
their having left off the
odious practice of entrapping
human prey to Moshesh
having given them cattle
They are d called Marimo
and Maya bathu = men eaters
by the rest of the BasutusBasuto
with various subdivisions
as Makatla, Bamakakana
105 109
Matlapatlapa &c -

The Bakoni farther North
than the BasutuBasuto are the
Batlou - Bapēri - Bapō and
another tribe of Bakuena - Bamosetla -
Bamapela or, Babiriri - Balaka
Bapiri
Bahukeng - Batlokua -
Baakhahela &c &c - The
whole of which tribes
are favoured with abundance
of rain and being much
attached to agriculture
raise very large quantities
of grain It is among
them that the more distant
boersBoers revel in slothful
abundance on their industry
and follow their slave
hunting and cattle stealing
propensities quite beyond
the range of English
influence and law - The
BasutuBasuto under Moshesh
are equally fond of cultivating
the soil The chief labour
of hoeing - driving away
birds, reaping, ^ & winnowing
falls to the willing arms
of the hard working women
but as the men ^ as already stated always
handle the hoe as well as
their wives many have
followed the advice of the
missionaries and now
106 110
use ploughs and oxen instead
of the hoe - Ju

Judging from questions
put to me in England it
seems to be not much
known that the South,
Africans, with the exception
of the Hottentots and Bushmen
are and always have been
agriculturalists - The want
It has never been
borne in mind of knowledge that in our
Caffre wars we have been
trying to wrest lands from
a people possessing in
a strong degree the same
feelings of attachment
to their father's
acresfields which would
rouse our yeomen from
Land's End to John o Groat'sJohn o' Groats'
house were they threatened
with invasion, is not
nor is this want of
knowledge much to be wondered at
here, ^ in England where we find since a gentleman
who had been thirty years
in the Cape Colony expressed
^ expressing at a public meeting
held in Cape town ^ in 1855 - expressed a strong
desire that that the
Caffres might become
an agricultural people -
a wish similar to what
a man might express if
he rose in the Mansion
House of London and
hoped the English would
learn to eat roast beef
107 111
for it is a fact patent to
everyone who has travelled
in the country that many
English tradesmen and
Dutch Bfarmers in the
Orange Free State are
almost entirely dependantdependent
on the BasutusBasutos for the
grain they consume - * (foot note)
* see two lectures
by RevdReverend E -
Solomon
delivered before
the Mechanics
InstituteMechanics' Institute Cape town
and generally the Zulus
of Natal can raise grain
cheap enough to drive
the Dutch African farmer
out of the market

3d The Bakalahari or
Western branch of the Bechuana
family consists of Barolong
Bahurutse - Bakuena
Bangwaketse Bakaa
Bakaa - Bamangwato
BakurutzeBakurutse Batauana
Bamatlaru Bamatlaro and Batlapi
Among the restlast the success
of missionaries havehas
been greatest - They were
an insignificant and
filthy people when first
discovered, and being
nearest to the Colony ^ they have
had opportunities of trading
and the long continued peace
they have enjoyed through
108 16112
the influence of religious
teaching has enabled them
to amass great numbers
of cattle - The young however
who do not realize their
former degradation often
consider their present
superiority overto the Interior
and less favoured tribes
in the interior ^ to be entirely owing to their
superior wisdom &
more intellectual develope-
mentdevelopment -

Having waited a
month at Linyanti we
again departed for the
purpose of ascending
the river from Sesheke
in company with Sekeletu
X and about 160 attendants
We had most of the young
men with us and many
of the underchiefs besides
The country between
Linyanti is perfectly
flat on patches elevated
only a few feet above
the surrounding level
There are also many
mounds where the
gigantic anthills of the
country have been
109 113
situated or still appear - These
mounds are evidently the work of
the termites - No one who
has not seen their gigantic
structures can fancy the
industry of the little labourers
They seem to impart fertility
to the soil which has
once passed through their
hands for the Makololo
find the declivity sides of
anthills the choice spots
for rearing ^ early maize or tobacco
or anything on which
they wish to bestow especial
care - In the parts through
which we passed the
mounds are generally
covered with masses
whil ^ of wild date trees - The
fruit is small and no
tree is allowed to
stand long for having
abundance of food the
Makololo have no
inclination to preserve
wild fruit trees and
accordingly when a
date shoots up to seed
so soon as when the fruit is ripe
they cut down the tree
rather than be at the
trouble of climbing it
The other parts of the
110 114
of more elevated land have
the camel thorn (acaciae giraffaeAcacia giraffae)
white thorned Mimosa mimosa (acacia horrida)
and baobabs - In sandy
spots there are palmyras
somewhat similar to the
Indian but with a smaller
seed - The soil on all
the flat parts which is a
rich dark tenacious loam
known as the cotton land
in India - It is covered
with a dense matting
of coarse grass
well known on all
damp spots on this country
We had the Chobe on our
right with its scores of
miles of reedy occupying
our horizon there - It
was pleasant to look
back on the long extended
line ^ of our attendants as it twisted
and bent
according to the
curves of
the foot paths
or in and out
behind the
mounds - with their
ostrich feathers waving
in the wind - Some wore
the ^ white ends of ox-tails on
their heads huzzarhussar
fashion and others great
bunches of black ostrich
feathers or caps ^ made of lion'slions'
manes - Some wore
red tunics or various
coloured prints which
the chief had bought from
Fleming - ^ the common men
111 115
carried burdens - Gentlemen
walked with a small club of
Rhinoceros horn in their
hands and had servants
to carry their shields while
the "Machaka" battle axe men
carried their own and
were liable at any time
to be sent of a hundred
miles and are expected
to run all the way -

Sekeletu is always
accompanied by his own
Mopato a number of
young men of his own
age When he sits down
they crowd round him
those who are nearest
eat out of the same dish -
for the Makololo chiefs
pride themselves on
eating with their people
He eats a little then
beckons his neighbours
to eat partake - When
they have eaten some he
may indicate to some
one at a distance to take
a share and that person
starts forward and seizes
the pot - removing it to
his own companions
The comrades of Sekeletu
wishing to imitate him
in riding on
112 116
in the possession of my
old horse, had a number
of half broken Batoka oxen
As they leaped on their
backs as they ran, and
having had neither saddle nor
bridle, the number of
tubmbles they met ^ with was a
source of much amusement
137 to the rest - Herds of Lechwes
or as they are here called Lechwes
appeared feeding quite
heedlessly all over the
flats - They exist here
in prodigious numbersherds
although the numbers
of them and ^ of the NakonNakong
that are killed annually must
be enormous - Both are
water antelopes and when
the lands we now tread
upon are flooded they
betake themselves to the
mounds weI have alluded
to - The Makalaka who
are most expert in the
management of their
thin light small ^ thin light canoes come gently
towards them - The men
stand in the canoe though
it is not more than fifteen
or eighteen inches wide
and about fifteen ^ feet long
their paddles 10 feet in
length and of a kind
113 117
of wood called Molompi, very
light yet as elastic as
ash - With these they either
punt or paddle according
to the depth shallowness or
depth of the water - When
they percieveperceive the antelopes
beginning to move they
increase their speed &
pursue the ^ them with great
velocity - They make
the water dash away from
the gunwale and though
the Leché goes off by a
succession of prodigious
bounds the its feet appearing
to touch the bottom each
time, they manage to
spear great numbers of them

The Nakong often shares
a similar fate - It is ^ a littlerather
smaller less than the Leché and
in shape has more of
paunchiness than any antelope
I ever saw - Its gait
resembles closely the gallop
of a dog when tired - The
hair ^ is long and rather sparse
so that it is never sleek
looking - It is of a brogreyish
brown colour and has
horns twisted in the manner
of a Khoodoo but much
smaller and with a double
ridge winding round each
114 118
of them -

Its habitat is the marsh
and muddy bogs - The great
length of foot between
the point of the toe and
supplemental hoofs enables
it to make a foot printmark
about a foot in length
It feeds by night and lies
hid among the reeds &
rushes by day - When
pursued theit dashes into
sedgy parts containing water
and immerses histhe whole
body, leaving only the mere
point of the nose exposed -
The natives burn
large patches of
reed
in order to drive
the Nakong
out of his lair and occasionally the point
ends of the horns appear and
when heit sees itself surrounded
by enemies in canoes - it
will rather allow theseits horns to
be scorched in the burning
reed than come forth from
its hiding place

When we arrived at any
village the women all
turned out to lulliloo their
chief - Their shrill voices
to which they give a tremulous
sound by a quick motion of the tongue peals
forth "Great Lion"! "Great
- chief"! "Sleep my Lord - " &c -
